item.title: rguide
item.description: It’s not as though there is any shortage of resources for getting started with R. Nonetheless, none of the existing guides do things exactly my way, so one more can’t possibly hurt. Here is my own step-by-step guide to getting started with R, to be updated as I find the time. Why use R? There are a few reasons why R is often the language of choice for academic research.
I have a wiki where I keep various notes and things not deigned blogworthy. You can find a list of things I find useful over here

item.title: Endorsements
item.description: Tech I recently switched to Linux for my primary personal computer. I use crouton on an Acer c720 Chromebook. It runs all day on a single charge and is extraordinarily capable, thank you very much. (I still keep my old macbook pro around for some things, but it’s increasingly just a data server). I blog and maintain my website using a combination of Octopress/Jekyll, markdown, nearlyfreespeech, and Git. Academic input Docear is the long-sought-after solution to my literature organization conundrum–and then some.
